metadata.title: A novel evaluation technique for Named Entity Recognition (NER) | by Charudatta Manwatkar | Dec, 2020 | Towards Data Science | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: A better way to evaluate Named Entity Recognition (NER) models
metadata.description: A new research paper is discussed here which presents new interpretable and fine-grained evaluation techniques for Named Entity Recognition (NER) .

all_paragraphs: NER is typically approached as a sequence labelling problem and the models for it are usually evaluated through traditional classification metrics such as precision, recall, F-score, etc. You can read a primer on the topic in this post.

These simple metrics are fine if you just want a quick comparison of different models, but they are really opaque and don’t tell you a lot. They don’t tell you anything about what are the strengths and weaknesses of the model or what characteristics of the data are most influential on the model performance.

You are left guessing whether the model is suffering due to long sentence length, or is it because there are too many (or too few) entities, the entities are spread out too far (or too close), or the entities are highly ambiguous, etc.

To tackle this problem, researchers from Carnegie Mellon University and Fudan University, China have come up with a novel evaluation technique which tackles some of these problems. You can read the original paper here.
The authors have also released an open source repository that has the implementation of the concepts in this paper.

This article is my attempt to explain the findings in this paper to a broader audience in a simplified way. It is in no way a complete and exhaustive reproduction of the paper. The original paper is rich in details and nuances, so do give it a read to know more.

The main idea in the paper is to divide the data into buckets of entities based on attributes such as entity length, label consistency, entity density, sentence length, etc. and then evaluate the model on each of these buckets separately.
This makes it easy to locate the factors where the model is performing (or not performing) well.
Let’s go into some of these details.
Attributes are different characteristics of the training examples, which may affect the performance of the model. These are:
‘New York’ is labelled as ‘LOC’, but in
“I study in New York University”
‘New York’ is a part of entity labelled ‘ORG’.

For any of the above-mentioned attributes, we may divide the dataset into as many buckets as we want (authors prefer 4 buckets). On each of these buckets, the model performance is measured by its micro-average F-1 score.
After gathering this diverse performance data, it’s time to find out the correlation between attributes and performance.
A typical reader would infer correlation between the model performance and the attribute values using Pearson Correlation Coefficient.
However the authors infer correlations not directly between F-1 scores and the attribute values, but between the ranks of the F-1 scores and the ranks of the attribute values.
My guess is that this allows the authors to create more convenient buckets which may not be strictly in the increasing order of the attribute values.
For this purpose, the authors use Spearman’s rank correlation coefficient. To test the significance of these correlations, they use the Friedman Test and Wilcoxon signed-rank test as appropriate.
To quote a wise man, “Don’t worry about it if you don’t understand it right away”.

This analysis is similar to how traditional multi-dataset analysis are performed (without fine-graining into attributes or buckets). The authors argue that it does not create a very clear picture of what are the crucial factors for the performance.

This is the analysis which takes full advantage of the new ideas presented in the paper. After measuring the performance of all the models on all the buckets of all the datasets, the authors present 2 methods to make sense of all the results.

The authors also characterize the datasets themselves in terms of average values of attribute values (without referring to any NER model at all). This gives us a great way to assess the character of a new dataset (which may be specific to a particular application). This kind of characterization may enable us to choose the model in an informed way (e.g. if your dataset has high OOV Density, then you might choose a CNN based model rather than BERT). With the use of these fine-grained and interpretable evaluation metrics, we can take informed decisions about how to improve model performance.
The authors present the case that since BERT and Flair are most sensitive to Label Consistency, adding more context to each training example would enable the model to make substantial improvement.
To test this hypothesis, they train the models again with multiple sentences in each training example. As a result, the performance of the model improves substantially.
— Find out which attributes of the data affect the performance the most.
— Choose the best suited model for a particular dataset in an informed way.
— Come up with well-grounded ideas for model improvement.

So, I hope this article helps you evaluate your NER models in a more meaningful way. If there is any part of the article which is not very clear or needs further discussion, please feel free to reach out to me.
I intend to write more such posts summarizing awesome new research papers. If that’s your thing, then be sure to follow me here.
